interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Review Date: 2016/09/13
Average Rating: 4.4
Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'alcohol use', 'foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English', 'English [Audio Description]'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Dan Trachtenberg'], 'Producers': ['J. J. Abrams', 'Lindsey Weber', 'Bryan Burk', 'Drew Goddard', 'Matt Reeves'], 'Starring': ['John Goodman', 'Mary Elizabeth Winstead', 'John Gallagher Jr.'], 'Studio': ['Paramount Pictures']}
Review Text: Very exciting and suspenseful. Overall a good movie. Although my son disagrees with me, I thought the ending was kind of weak and could have been resolved better. The ending is a pretty jarring transition from the unreliable narrator, psychological suspense to a kind of action movie. I love the reality of the ending (the story line), I just don't think the movie pulls it off very well.
Review Title: Very suspenseful and exciting
Rating: 4.0
--------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
The Book of Eli
Suspense, Drama, Bleak, Gritty
['A lone warrior (Denzel Washington) wanders the post-apocalyptic desert that was once America, battling lawlessness to realize his hope of a better future.']

A bit violent for some, no doubt, but great acting and good story
but great acting and good

Great story!
{'Content advisory': ['Nudity', 'violence', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English', 'English [Audio Description]'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Ron Howard'], 'Producers': ['Brian Grazer', 'John Calley'], 'Starring': ['Tom Hanks', 'Audrey Tautou', 'Jean Reno']}
Doesn't hold up to the book, but it's a pretty good movie
Pretty good
{'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Mike Judge'], 'Producers': ['Mike Judge', 'Elysa Koplovitz'], 'Starring': ['Luke Wilson', 'Maya Rudolph', 'Dax Shepard'], 'Studio': ['20TH CENTURY FOX']}
I've given it 4 stars, not because I'm suggesting it falls in the same category with many other great movies, but for it's social commentary. It can be rather silly at times, with some classic B-movie antics, but it really does nail many aspects of social decline. Overall entertaining, with a few surprise laugh-out-loud moments.
Great social commentary, with some pretty funny moments!
{'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'frightening scenes', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Ridley Scott'], 'Producers': ['Gordon Carroll', 'David Giler', 'Walter Hill'], 'Starring': ['Tom Skerritt', 'Sigourney Weaver', 'John Hurt'], 'Studio': ['20TH CENTURY FOX']}
A few of the effects are dated, but it is amazing how well this 1979 movie stands the test of time. I guess a great movie is always just that.
This classic stands the test of time

Very exciting and suspenseful. Overall a good movie. Although my son disagrees with me, I thought the ending was kind of weak and could have been resolved better. The ending is a pretty jarring transition from the unreliable narrator, psychological suspense to a kind of action movie. I love the reality of the ending (the story line), I just don't think the movie pulls it off very well.

profile:
**Updated User Profile Summary:**

This user maintains a strong enthusiasm for suspenseful and dramatic content, particularly favoring gritty and post-apocalyptic narratives. They appreciate storytelling across various tones, as demonstrated by their engagement with films that blend psychological suspense with action elements. Their critiques reveal a discerning palate, often recognizing the artistry behind both classic and contemporary works, even when certain narrative transitions fall short of expectations.

The user is drawn to films that provide sharp social commentary, skilled acting, and complex storytelling, while also embracing absurdities without sacrificing narrative integrity. Their recent review highlighted a mixed response to a film's climactic shift, indicating their preference for cohesive resolutions that maintain psychological tension. Despite any reservations, they rate films on thematic relevance, demonstrating an ability to find enjoyment and humor in unexpected narrative twists.

Their consistent interest in intense themes signifies a tolerance for violence, especially when it complements strong performances. Overall, the user exemplifies a thoughtful and engaged viewer, appreciating cinematic artistry that challenges and entertains. They continue to explore diverse narratives within their favored genres, celebrating emotional resonance and innovative storytelling, whether comedic or dramatic. This balanced perspective ensures their ongoing appreciation for the craft of filmmaking.
